bibl.title: Letter fragment from Walter Reed to Emilie Lawrence Reed July 21, 1879

div1.p: Reed writes about finances, promising to send money to her. She wants him to get an eastern assignment. He gives news about acquaintances.

div1.head: Letter fragment from Walter Reed to Emilie Lawrence Reed July 21, 1879
div1.p:
Your
“feetuing etsig,” dated Harrison-
burg; July 5th, & mailed on the 6th, reached
Apache, yesterday afternoon, the 20th,
old mantee was mighty glad to
hear that you had gotten out of
Washington, “right side up with
care”, and reached H'burg safely-
But poor little darling wifie,
mantee is so sorry that she didn't
have any money left in her little
darling pocket! Love her heart!
mantee should have given his
little darling more money, for
suppose she should have spent
all her money in W. & had
none to take her to the Valley!
wouldn't it have been dreadful,
my lovie? I “pec”, however, that
my sweet little wifie knew
what she was doing & gauged
her money so that she could get
all the enjoyment out of it
that was possible & have just
enough to pay her car-fare to
Grandma Reeds! Bless your
sweet, affectionate heart, that
was exactly right, my darling
wife, & just what mantee wanted
& told you to do. He is so happy
to think that your few dollars
afforded you so much enjoy-
-ment, and thinks you did very
well to make it last till July
1st. Of course, your actual
expenses will be very little
in H'burg, as there is nothing
very particular to see. You pay
your Nurse $4.00 a month & I guess
your washing & Laurie's will cost
$5.00 a month. Mantee has $75.00
now, ready & waiting to be sent
to his precious wifie, if the Pay-
-master would only come along.
I don't know when he will be
here, & as Col. Compton will
leave here to-morrow or wednes-
day, on his way to Santa Fe, I
have a great notion to give
him the money & let him draw
a check in Santa Fe & forward
to you. I could also have an
excellent opportunity to send the
money to pay for your necklace,
if it was done - but I have
not yet received the bill from
Mr Lucas. I have got the money
ready to pay for it - besides the $75.
to send to you, lovie, and enough to
pay all my July expenses. Now I
“fink” that is doing “wight” well,
to be able to cancel all the ex-
penses of our journey; to pay
my own expenses for half of May
all of June & July expenses & to send my wifie
$75.00 & pay $75.00 for her necklace.
And all of this out of our June & July
pay! Of course, I shouldn't have
been able to have done so, had I
not sold my rifle & shot-gun &
our chairs, which together brought
me $56.00, which added to our June &
July pay made $322.00, from which
I had to draw, & it has just taken
it all. So that we begin August,
lovie, out of debt & $75.00 on its way
to your to help pay your expenses
till mantee comes - Seven months
pay, or $933.00, has done very well,
I think, to pay our expenses, & enable
you to go east & enjoy yourself.
we have still five months pay
or $666.00 left, & I think, lovie, with
care, this will defray our expenses
for the remainder of the year & ena-
ble us to save something to buy
our carpets, chairs & c- Don't my
little darling think so? I will let
you know at the end of my letter whether
I send the money by Col. Compton or not,
Page 5- So you called on Doctor
Otis, my little wifie? you are right
in saying that he appears dull &
queer- He is truly unattractive,
but he is, for all that, darling, an
exceedingly intelligent man:a most
excellent writer, & a very hard
student. Mrs. Harrison says he
used to be quite a different
looking man, but he has had great
family afflictions, & is himself
suffering now from a mortal
malady of the spine. Of course,
he could tell you nothing in
the world about the changes,
for he hasn't a thing to do with
it, any more than I have, but
it was very good & sweet in
my little darling to go to him &
try to find out. If you had only
gone to the Surgeon General,
you might have learned something,
but it is doubtful whether
you could have got any in-
-formation, even there. They are
very queer at Headquarters &
very chary about telling any-
-thing. But I presume it is so
because officer's wifves would
be continually running & beg-
-ging for this & that change, if it
were possible to obtain it-
And you were so delighted
with Washington, that you
would like to be stationed there.
Well, precious, as for me, it
is just the last place, I should
care to be stationed at- Why,
my little wifie, our salary wouldn't
support us in W.- What
will my pretty Emilie say
when she gets old mantee's
letter asking her how she
would like Fort Union? I guess
she will just run around
the room & tear her hair at
the very thought of it! I “pec”
my little lovie likes the East
better than the west - and for
her darling sake, I do hope
that we will get some pleas-
-ant Eastern Post, where my
precious Emilie can have an
opportunity of seeing interes-
-ting sights & a chanche to pur-
sue her art-studies. I am
so happy, darling, that you
got the books & materials, &
I so much wish my little
lovie would devote herself
to improving her talents for
painting- Nothing would
please your poor old Man-
-tee more. He would afford
you every facility that his
means would permit, & do
it, Emilie, darling, so gladly!
I trust you will have a
real pleasant time in the
valley with Sister Annie
and Ma Reed, & that you
will grow fat & kick & be
a sweet, plump arm-full
for mantee when he comes.
You must get some good books
& read them, & then write a heap
of long letters to old mantee.
Hereafter, I will put more stamps
on my letters, lovie, so that you
will not be bothered. I don't
see how my letter to ma could
have been mailed the 22nd, unless
You mean, “post marked 22nd
at St. Joseph- I have sent you
letters, my darling, since June
began, on the following dates:
June 3rd, 10th, 17th 24th, 30th;
July 8th, July 13th & 15th- See
if you have not got them
all lovie. I should hate
for any of my letters to
miscarry, for I can only send
them but once a week.
Page 9. Tuesday, July 22nd79. I find, my
darling wife, that it is uncertain
just when Col. Compton will
leave Apache, as it seems likely
that he will have to remain
till the New Commanding Officer,
Major Cochran, 12 Infantry, arrives.
On this account, I have thought
it best to find some other & quick-
er way of getting some money
to you, as I am afraid my
little darling will be put to
trouble by the want of it.
It fortunately happens that Mrs.
Harrison has a check on
Treasury, in Washington, for
$60.00 & this I have got from
her, & made it payable to your
order- The other $15.00, to make
up the $75.00, I will send by the
Paymaster when he comes, as
I am determined that my pretty
picture shall have every cent
of her $75.00. Yes, she “sal” have it!
When you get this check, get
Ma to go down to the bank with
you & get the money, & then
the first thing you do, buy a
pound of real nice candy
& fill your “tummick” with it,
but don't get the “pelly”-ache,
my little lovie. Take mighty
good care of your precious
health and our sweet little
darling's, and don't let any ac-
-cident befall either of your
precious selves. You know
old mantee hasn't got any other
little darlings in this world,
and if anything should happen
to his lovie's or Laurie's welfare,
he don't know what he would
do. They are the one bright spot
in his life that he can look
back to with pride & pleasure,
& to which he looks forward
to with so much hope, love.
Page 13- Last evening, lovie,
we were all invited down to
the Post Trader's to an enter-
tainment given to Col. & Mrs. C.
on the eve of their departure.
We all assembled in the new
billiard room & had a very en-
-joyable time. Even Captain
Adam K, & Captain Jack Viven,
& Cap't. Mc Gowan were there.
We had music, some dancing,
and plenty of good salad with
mayonnaise dressing, & just enough
Champagne to drive away in-
-digestion. The three ladies were
dressed in their best & all looked
very well. We stayed till mid-
-night & came home through
a nice shower of rain - I es-
-corted “Jen”. By the way, Captain
Adam seems to have abandoned
his last hope. He heeds no
more the soothing ditty, “there's
a light in the window for thee,
Adam”- There is no “eye to mark
his coming & grow brighter when
he comes”; because he doesn't
go! Has not been to Captain
Hentig's for a month, and seems
to give himself “no thought for the
morrow”, so to speak- Captain
Alexander Bartholomew McGowan,
for such is the abbreviated name
of the new additions, calls suf-
-ficiently often and we tease
Mrs. Harrison a good deal about
him - at least Mrs. C. & I do- all
of which she bears in a very
jolly manner. I think, however,
that “Barty”, as we call him “for
short,” doesn't stand much of
a chance, because he has the
habit, when a little excited,
of just Knocking the “King's Eng-
-lish” into a “cocked hat,” and this
Mrs. H. doesn't relish one bit.
So perhaps after all, the maiden,
with the bright, black eye, will
leave Arizona with a “heart so
free”! Did I tell you about my
nice little cat & beautiful pup-
-py that I have? Well, my little
wifie, after little Undie died, the
house seemed so lonely that I had
to have something about to keep
me company- So I & the Secretary
to his Holiness, looked around & finally
succeeded in getting a splendid,
puppy - a real big fellow, half
setter & half Newfoundland - and
then “Mrs. Mahoney, dear,” presen-
ted me with a half grown
cat - and I considered myself
happy once more. But bless
your soul, my pretty wifie, they
have driven me nearly crazy-
I tried them for three night's
in the house, & such a racket
never was heard in this world.
I couldn't sleep a wink- I ex-
-cluded the pup from the house
at night & let the cat stay in-
Result- The pup howled & scratched
all night at the backed door, &
the cat tried her best to get out,
Consequently I excluded her the
next night, but as she was a fe-
male cat & Tom Hentig is not
a female cat, they gave me such
a concert as nearly drove me
wild - Result - cat sent back
next morning with many regrets
to “Mrs. Mahoney, dear”, & the dog kept
in the out-house at night. Thus
I managed at last, to get some
sleep. The pup is very playful
& much company too, but as he has
a few puppy failings, he is mostly
excluded from the “boudoir”- But
I must stop, lovie- Bear this in mind,
darling, & obey strictly. As soon as
you get this letter, write at once &
acknowledge receipt of check- Don't
forget this! Best love to all-
A thousand sweet kisses for mother
& son - & a heap of love- Write
very often to your own loved & devoted
husband,
